titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
Morning visit from Mr. Heman Lincoln. He has been here for some weeks as Agent, for the Baptist Board of Foreign Missions; and is in frequent communication with the Indian Division of the War Department here concerning the relations between our Government and the Indian Tribes and there is a constant interposition of this Association, in the negotiation and execution of their Treaties with the United States— He told me a long story, of Treaties made in the years 1835. and 36. with the Ottoway and Chippeway Tribes, and the discordant movements between the Baptist Missionary on that station and Roman Catholic Priests, in competition with them for the conversion of the Tribes to the Christian Faith;—It is a melancholy
contemplation that these pious purposes, in profession common to them both, are more strongly marked by jealousy and hatred of each other, than by their success, in Christianizing the heathen Savage— More characteristic, of the boundless ambition of the Papal power, than of the progress, of the Kingdom of Christ upon Earth— At the House, John. H McHenry, asked leave to give notice, of a long complicated and quite useless, addition to the rules, for, proceedings in Committee of the whole to which objection being made, he moved to suspend the rules, to enable him to give the notice; which the House refused, At Dromgoole’s motion, the House went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, J. R. J. Daniel of North Carolina, in the Chair, and took up, the Sub-Treasury Bill— Which was debated by Henry Grider of Kentucky Washington Hunt of New York, and Garrett Davis of Kentucky against the Bill and John H Harmanson of Louisiana Wm. Sawyer of Ohio—Daniel of North Carolina who yielded for the time, the Chair to McDowell of Ohio and George W. Jones of Tennessee, till at a quarter before five the Committee rose and after an abortive effort, to adjourn, till ten oclock, tomorrow, they adjourned till eleven— A remarkable explosion took place this day, in the Senate, upon the Oregon Notice Question— Thomas H. Benton came out for 49. against Lewis Cass, of Michigan, and the 54.40. men, He was replied to, with great bitterness by Hannegan of Indiana— The Administration Democrats, are splitting up into fragments— There is a great probability, that the Whigs will do the same, and a new organization of Parties, be formed on the basis, of the Oregon Question— Evening visits from Mr. George Sykes, with Mr. Stephens and Mr. Ryder two of his Constituents from New Jersey— The debate in the House this day was so dull, that
I escaped from it, and gave a sitting of an hour, to Mr. Johnson, in a Committee Room below for my Portrait—

I forgot to mention that Mr. Richard. I. Morsell, came last evening, and made his Annual payment of three hundred dollars conformably to his contract, with me, of the 31st. March, 1840— I should have mentioned also, that Mr. Heman Lincoln yesterday returned to me, the Manuscript Lecture upon Faith which I had lent him, and of which he told me, he had taken a Copy, as I had given him permission to do— At the House, the reading of the Journal of yesterday was dispensed with, a bad practise which I strongly apprehend, will become a general one— They went immediately into Committee of the whole, on the state of the Union, Daniel of North Carolina in the Chair, and took up the Sub Treasury Bill— Garrett Davis of Kentucky finished the Speech which he had commenced yesterday, and Dromgoole, who had introduced the Bill replied to all its oponents leaving only ten minutes to Barkly Martin of Tenn in the course of which he found an opportunity of quoting my authority, in favour of the Bill by referrence to my vote, in favour of General Gordon’s Amendment offered to a Bill, in 1834, which Amendment he represented, as identical with the Bill now before this Committee— I rose, and asked him to allow me, but one moment, to explain my reason for that vote— But he said he could not spare it from his allotted 10. minutes, and after some pleasantry, I surrendered my claim, for liberty to explain— I had voted for Gordons Bill as an Amendment to one still more obnoxious, intending if the Amend
ment had prevailed, finally to vote against it— This is a very common, but very disingenous practise, of adducing, a former vote upon an Amendment, as a substitute for a different provision, and concluding from it, that the voter is pledged in favor of the Amendment when substituted— At one o’clock, the time for closing the debate, came; and a multitude of Amendments were voted upon by the Committee, many of them, rejected, a few adopted, and the Bill was reported to the House— The previous Question was immediately started, and the Bill finally passed, by yeas and nays, 123. to 67— Dromgoole moved, a ridiculous alteration of the, title, itself as long, as a moderate sized Bill, it was rejected, and the title first proposed adopted, and at half past three, the House, adjourned— The smart and spicy debate, between Thomas. H Benton, and Lewis Cass, in the Senate, was this day, continued, and concluded, leaving the Parties, precisely where they were when commenced, between 49. and 54–40. Mr. W. G. Robinson the expelled reporter, for the New York Tribune, was here this evening, with Mr. Dempster the Musician, who entertained us, with several melancholy, and one lively Song.

As the Spring advances, I am suffering with flying shoots of rheumatism, which disturb my nightly rests, and encroach upon my rising hour— It unsettles also, my mind, and fills it, with teeming fancies which never come to maturity— “AEgri-somnia” At the House, Archibald Atkinson of Virginia—offered a resolution, calling on the Secretary of the Navy, for a Report on the pay and emoluments of the Marine Corps, which was carried by a suspension of the rules. Albert Constable of Maryland presented sundry resolutions, of the Legislature of that State, and the House went into Committee of the
whole, and took up the Bill, to provide for the continuation, of the Cumberland Road, in the States of Ohio, Indiana, and Illinois— W. W. Wick of Indiana, moved as an Amendment, to substitute a Bill, reported from the committee on Roads and Canals, granting to those several states, Land instead of money, to pay for the continuance of that Road.— This Bill with this, and sundry other Amendments, was very earnestly, and tediously debated, between the Western, and Southern members—till the Committee rose, and Lynn Boyd of Kentucky offered a Resolution, to close the debate in Committee in half an hour, after it should again be taken up— Vinton of Ohio moved to lay this motion upon the Table, but there was no quorum voting, and after two, or three, failures, of motions to adjourn, it was carried, about four o’clock by yeas and nays 59 to 55— In the Senate, the War between the degrees of Latitude, in Oregon, was continued and Daniel Webster, gave notice, that next Monday, he would speak, in defence, of his Ashburton Treaty; against sundry collateral attacks made against it, in the Oregon debates— Mr. W. Hogan, was here this evening, and mentioned to me, that the Union Newspaper of this day, contained a Letter, from Robert Greenhow, in defence of his History of Oregon and California against a furious assault, of Thomas. H. Benton, upon it in his Speech, two days ago in the Senate, and Mr. Hogan afterwards sent me the Paper— There is an onerous coalition or as Rhett of South Carolina, would call it a disastrous conjunction, upon this subject, between the Senators, Benton, Webster, and Calhoun—the final results of which are yet in the womb of time.

Mr. Wilson, came here this morning, about the Lot, adjoining, that in which their House stands, which I had conditionally promised, to
let him have upon a Lease for a Garden— I had since, determined, not to let him have it, but he says, that in the confidence of my promise he had proceeded to make the repairs, which I had required, and had actually, sown the seeds, of vegetables, in the ground— Though I thought he had no right to do this, to avoid a quarrel with a neighbour, of all things the most odious, I told him, I would endeavour, to make arrangements upon which, we might agree, and he promised, to call again, in the course of next week— Mr. John Sergeant, brought his Bill for Binding 20 Vol. of Pub. Doc. which I paid—3. Vol. of which, are yet to be delivered— At the House, the resolution moved yesterday by Lynn Boyd to close the debate, in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union upon the Cumberland Road Bill, in half an hour after it shall be again taken up, was resumed. Mr. Ashman, had moved to lay it on the Table, which was now refused, and Boyd, substituted two hours, instead of half an hour, for further debate, yeas and nays 94. to 63. The House then went into Committee of the whole, on the Private Calender 79. to 36— Howell Cobb of Georgia in the Chair— It was taken up at the point, where the Committee had stopped this day last week, upon which Private Bills were debated— A Bill for the relief of William Culver, was discussed and laid aside to be reported— The next Bill, was for the allowance, of a bounty, on the Fishing Schooner Success—lost at Sea, twenty, before completing her voyage of four months— It was opposed by Samuel Gordon of New York—Daniel of North Carolina—Bowlin of Missouri and George S. Houston of Alabama and supported by Hamlin of Maine, Daniel. P. King—W. W. Campbell—J. A. Rockwell, of Connecticut and Robert McClelland of Michigan— The policy of the Fishing Bounties was controverted, chiefly between the East and West, till the Committee dwindled down, till com-
pelled to rise, for lack of a quorum. A Motion to adjourn was made, upon which the yeas and nays were called, and refused, and about two o’clock, the House adjourned, and thus it is that they transact the business upon the days assigned, for the consideration of Private Claims—and fortunate exposition of the Laws delay— I had spoken yesterday to Morgan. L. Martin the Delegate from the Territory of Wisconsin of a paragraph in a Newspaper mentioning the assassination of Finley J. Hamilton of Green Bay— He said he had a Letter from his daughter, dated the 12th. of last month, three days, after the event, and telling all its circumstances, and stating, that Mr. Hamilton, was yet living and while there was Life there was hope— He said he was well acquainted with Mr. Hamilton, who had married the daughter of Mr. Boyd, who was and had been for twenty years a neighbour of Mr. Boyd and intimate with his family— Mr. Lewis Rall, from Cincinnati Ohio, an Agent for Sundry Claimants for Pensions and Bounty Lands— He asked my advice and assistance, with information, to obtain the Claims, and I referred him first, to the Commissioner of Pensions—James. L. Edwards.

I attended Public Service, this morning, where Mr. Tustin the Chaplain of the Senate, made the prayer and Dr. Junkin, President of Lafayette College at Easton Pennsylvania preached, from John 3.1. “There was a man of the Pharisnamed Nicodemus a ruler of the Jews. 2. The same came to Jesus by night, and said unto him Rabbi, we know that thou art a Teacher, come from God, for no man can do these miracles that thou doest except God be with him— 3. Jesus answered and said unto him verily, verily I say unto thee, except a man be born again, he cannot see the King
dom of God 4. Nicodemus saith unto him, how can a man be born when he is old can he enter the second time, into his mothers womb, and be born. 5. Jesus answered verily, verily I say unto thee, except a man be born of water and of the Spirit, he cannot enter, into the Kingdom of God. 6. That which is born of the Flesh is flesh, and that which is born of the Spirit, is Spirit. 7. marvel not that I said unto thee, ye must be born again. 8. The wind bloweth where it listeth, and thou hearest the sound thereof, but canst not tell whence it cometh and whither it goeth, so is every one that is born of the Spirit 9. Nicodemus answered an said unto him, how can these things be— 10. Jesus answered and said unto him, art thou a master of Israel, and knowest not these things.” This text comprises the whole Roman Catholic and Calvanistic—doctrine of re-generation— A creed, upon which the most rigorous reformer from Popery, did not separate from the Church of Rome. It is the most mysterious of all the Doctrines of Christianity, though, if illustrated, by the exclamation of being born of water that is, by baptism & of the Spirit, and by the figurative exposition of the blowing of the wind, I understand as meaning by the Kingdom of God, nothing more than Faith in the Divine Mission of Jesus Christ, and obedience to his commands— Dr. Junkin’s exposition was more comprehensive and included much of the metaphysics of Calvin— After dinner I attended at the 2. Presbyterian Church, where Mr. Matthew Hale Smith, the present Minister commenced his course of Sermons, addressed to young persons, by taking for his text Psalm 119.9. “Wherewithal shall a young man cleanse his way? by taking heed thereto, according to thy word”— Mr. Smith gave notice that there would be a third Service, at 7 o’clock this evening, at that Church, and that his Sermon of next Sunday afternoon, would be addressed to young women. The pews of the Church, were filled, more
than I think I have ever seen them before. Mr. William. A. Mosely of Buffalo Member of the House from the 32d. Congressional District of New York a man of intelligence, courteous deportment and pleasant conversation, was here this evening— We had also evening visits from Richard. D. Cutts and his Sister—

Mr. Lewis Rall of Cincinnati was here this morning— At my recommendation, he went to the Office of Commissioner of Pensions and left with him, the documents in support of the Claims of several persons, to Pensions, and Bounty Lands, requesting Mr. Edwards to report upon them to me within a term of about twenty days, during which he proposed to visit Boston and return to this place— He requested also, my attention, to these Claims in his absence, and left a List of them with me— They are 23 in number, but the Vouchers in support of them, are all in the hands of Mr. Edwards— At the House, the call for Petitions, was overlooked and the Committees were called for Reports— An attempt was made to obtain a suspension of the rules for the introduction of Resolutions, but without success— Hannibal Hamlin of Maine, reported from the Committee of Elections there request to be discharged from the consideration of a Petition from the Citizens of Dover, in New Hampshire, remonstrating against the right of the Members now sitting, from elected by general Ticket, in violation of the Constitution of the United States, and of the District Law of Congress— Culver, moved, that the Petition be recommitted, to the Committee of Elections, with motions to enquire and report whether the sitting Members from New Hampshire were duly elected and if not, that their Seats be vacated. He supported his motion by a Speech, but Jacob Brinkerhoff of Ohio moved to lay the whole subject on the Table which was carried by yeas and nays 94. to 55—
Among the multitude of Reports from the Committees was a Bill, by Rathbun, from the Committee on the Judiciary creating the Office of Assistant Secretary of State, and for other purposes.— After the Reports from the Committees were all made, the House went into Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, Robert McClernand of Michigan in the Chair, and took up the Bill, for the continuance of the Cumberland Road— Numerous Amendments, were proposed, and adopted or rejected, till a Bill appropriating Land instead of Money; was substituted instead of the Bill reported, by the Committee on Roads and Canals, and was reported to the House, 83. to 35— Dromgoole moved to lay on the Table rejected, 74 to 84— There was some entanglement by an appeal, from a decision of the Speaker, upon a point of order, which was sustained, by the House, After which the House adjourned— Mr. Daniel Webster took three hours of this day in the Senate with a Speech in defence of his Ashburton Treaty, to be continued tomorrow— General Daniel Parker died last night about Six o’clock—

I have been suffering, for several days, with shoots of flying rheumatism, which disturb my repose in the night, and are now afflicting me with hoarseness and sore throat—which subsided however much in the course of this day— Mr. Bacon President of the Columbia College with Mr. and Mrs. Hall, a Sister of Mrs. Bacon, residing at Charlestown Mass. were here this morning. Also Mrs. Stebbins and Mr. Joseph Harrod on their way from New Orleans to Massachusetts.— Mr. Webster, finished in three hours this day his Speech of self vindication, and glorification of his Ashburton Treaty, against the assaults of Charles. J. Ingersoll—in the House and of Daniel. S. Dickinson Senator from the State of New York— More than half of the Members of the
House of Representatives, having deserted their Seats to hear him— Most of the day in the House, was consumed in taking the Questions by yeas and nays upon the Cumberland Road Bill, and the Amendments proposed to it. It began by a Call of the House, in the process of which 168. Members answered to their names, and further proceedings were then dispensed with. The first Question was upon the Substitute reported from the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, for the original Bill, this substitute consisted, of a grant of Lands, instead of an appropriation of money for the continuance of the Road; with an Amendment offered by Garrett Davis, of a grant of 500.000 Acres of Land to several states of the Union in consideration of similar grants, already made to others of the States.— There was a very captious debate, whether the substitute and the Amendment, jointly forming the report from the Committee, should be divided so as to take separate Questions on its two parts— The Speaker decided that they could not— The House rejected the Report from the Committee, by yeas and nays 77. to 103. and then the original Bill itself there 70. to 106— Rathbun moved a re-consideration and the Previous Question. Schenck moved to lay the Motion to reconsider on the Table, which was refused and then the motion to re-consider was rejected— The Bill is therefore dead. The House went into Committee of the whole on the State of the Union. McClernand of Illinois, in the Chair, and after some struggling, and two Appeals from the Chairman, the Bill was taken up, to raise a Regiment of Mounted Riflemen, and to erect Military Posts, on the route to Oregon After some debate upon small trifles of Amendment Lewis. C. Levin, of Pennsylvania, moved an Amendment provided “that the Officers and Soldiers, of said Regiment shall be Americans by birth” and he made a native American hour Speech— He was answered, by George C. Dromgoole, of Virginia in a
mellow Speech, also of an hour, Sarcastic and ludicrous—after which, the Committee rose, and the House adjourned.

I have been, several days, occupying my Leisure, in answering a Letter from Joseph Sturge of Birmingham, in England, complaining, of my Speech, on the Oregon Question, and charging me, with inflaming the temper of my Countrymen, to War.— Sturge is a Quaker, and a leading Member of the English Abolition Society— His motives are good, and his character, highly respectable— I have therefore, disclaiming all intention to kindle War, upon this Question, and professing a full concurrence with him, in abhorrence, of all agressive War I have marked the distinction, which should be made between that sentiment, and the unqualified denunciation of War, peculiar to the Doctrines of the Society of Friends, to which I cannot subscribe The Question of War and Peace, is identical, with the Question of Right and wrong— War for the Right, can never be justly blamed. War for the Wrong can never be justified.— In the House, immediately after the reading of the Journal, Jacob Brinkerhoff, moved to go into Committee of the whole, on the state of the Union, but withdrew the motion at my request, to introduce, a Resolution calling on the President, to cause to be communicated to the House if not incompatible with Public interest Copies of the Correspondence, of George William Gordon, late Consul of the United States at Rio de Janeiro with the Department of State, relating to the Slave Trade, in Vessels, and by Citizens of the United States, between the Coast of Africa and Brazil— Which resolution was adopted without opposition. The House then went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Reuben Chapman of Alabama in the Chair, and took up the Bill from the Senate, to raise a Regiment of Mounted Riflemen and for the erection of Military Posts for the safety and protection of Immigrants, on the route to Oregon— Sundry Amendments were proposed, and the debated resumed, upon the pro
viso moved by Mr. Levin, that the Officers and Men of this Regiment should be native Americans The Native American principle was strenuously sustained by W. W. Campbell, and Thomas. M. Woodruff members from the City of New York elected during the popular triumph in that City, on the Native American Party— But that Party finds no favor in this House.— They were encountered, by F. P. Stanton of Tennessee, Chipman of Michigan McConnell of Alabama, and sundry others. Hugh White of New York, moved that the Officers should be selected from the present Officers of the regular Army, and George W. Hopkins moved the establishment of a Post route— Both which propositions gave rise to desultory debate, till the Committee rose, McClernand, of Illinois, moved a resolution, granting the use of the Hall tomorrow evening for the Tutors and Pupils of the New York Institution for the Deaf and Dumb.— On taking the vote there was no quorum, and the House adjourned— Evening visits from Mr. Hogan and Mr. Goldsborough

I had sent and given notice to the Members of the Committee of Manufactures, to attend a meeting of the Committee, at 10 o’clock this morning— The Meeting was accordingly held. Present—Adams, Woodward, Stewart, Hudson, Yancey, Johnson, absent, Brown, Wilmot, Martin— There had been, since the 13. January a memorial from certain Fire Brick Makers in Virginia refered to the Committee, and on the 4th. of this Month, a Petition from certain Citizens of New Hampshire on the reduction of the Tariff. There being no other business refered to the Committee they had not met for several months.— I now proposed that the Chairman should be instructed to report to the House the request to be discharged from the consideration of these Memorials, and that they should be refered to the Committee of Ways and Means, which was unanimously agreed to— I had also
received from a person at Providence Rhode Island named Shephard of Oil of Vitreal a Letter, earnestly requesting, that the Impost Duty, levied upon the retorts, used for the manufacture of that Article, should be reduced or repealed— I read the Letter to the Committee and proposed to refer, that also, to the Chairman of the Committee of Ways and means—to which they agreed— The Committee then having no further business before them adjourned, without day— On repairing to the House I found Charles. J. Ingersoll, under color of making personal explanation, reading a written paper, charging Daniel Webster, with fraud and corruption, in his Official Station, as Secretary of State, during the Administration of John Tyler, which he closed with offering two Resolutions, calling upon the Secretary of State, to furnish the House, an account of all payments made on Presidents Certificates, from the Fund appropriated by Law, through the Agency, of that Department, for the contingent expenses of Foreign intercourse since the 4th. March 1841. with Copies of all other Papers, concerning the North Eastern Boundary dispute, with Great Britain and all papers, concerning a wish of President Tyler to institute a Special Mission to Great Britain, and of all correspondence, with any person in New York concerning Alexander McLeod— And another Resolution requiring the Chairman of the Committee of Foreign Affairs to submit to the House the Journal or minutes of that Committee, during the last Session, of the 27th. Congress.— A long debate ensued, in which I took a part, with many others— It closed with the adoption of the Resolutions substituting a Call upon the President, instead of the Secretary of State, by yeas and nays 136. to 28— The use of the Hall was granted for to-morrow evening to the Deputation from the New York Institution for the Instruction of the Deaf and Dumb Haralson of Georgia, moved a resolution, to close debate in Committee of the whole on the State of the Union on the Bill, to raise an additional Regiment of Mounted Riflemen, and for the construction of Military
Posts for the protection of Emigrants to Oregon, in one hour after it should be again taken up in Committee Jacob Thompson—moved to substitute two hours for one, but his Amendment was rejected and Haralsons motion carried by the Previous Question— Thomas Bayly moved a Call on the President, for the correspondence in 1841. between President Tyler and the Governor of New York relative to the appearance, of Joshua. A. Spencer District Attorney of the United States, for the Western District of New York, in the Courts of the State of New York as Council, for Alexander McLeod— George Ashmun, moved an Amendment, calling upon the Secretary of State, to inform the House, whether any person has been permitted to violate the secrecy of that Department, by examination of secret Papers in his keeping and whether he has communicated to any persons, the contents of such papers and if so to whom and when— George W. Hopkins, in the Speakers Chair, ruled this Amendment out of Order from which Ashmun appealed, and the House adjourned— Ashmun motion, was founded upon a suspicion that Ingersoll’s resolutions, were prepared by a concerted onset? between him, and the present Secretary of State Buchanan, against Daniel Webster— Of which there is little doubt, but which their Party will not suffer to be exposed— We had one evening visitor, Mr. Hogan, Son, of the gentleman, who was here last evening—

Dr. Thomas called here this morning— My health is wretched, and he prescribes from time to time, for ills, not within the reach of remedy—and for which the only medicine is Patience and resignation— I write verses, to beguile the time and attend the House to witness evils, greater than my own— This morning I found, Henry. William. Hilliard. of the 2d. Congressional District Alabama making a personal explanation of his Speech yesterday in defence and glorification,
of Daniel Webster, and which had been sharply taken up, by his Colleague, William. L. Yancey. of the 3d. Congressional District of the same State, whose malignant invective, far transcended the panegyric of Mr. Hilliard. His explanation, only gave occasion to Yancey to renew, with more envenomed bitterness, his charges against Webster—who is at this time pursued, with a rancour, perhaps never surpassed, by any persecution, ever, practised in this Country against any Public Man. It is one of the features of the present times, which I most deeply deplore—

After some discussion, upon the Appeal, by Mr. Ashmun, from the decision of Hopkins acting as Speaker, ruling out of Order Ashmun’s proposed Amendment to the Resolution offered by Thomas H. Bayly, for copies of the correspondence, in 1841. between the President of the United States and the Governor of New York, relating to the case of McLeod, Howell Cobb of Georgia, moved to lay the Appeal on the Table, was carried, by yeas and nays, 105 to 62, and Bayly’s motion, passed under the Previous Question without a division— James Dixon of Connecticut, moved a re-consideration, of the vote, of yesterday adopting the resolutions presented by Charles. J. Ingersoll— Objections were made, that a re-consideration, could not be had, upon, a Document, which had passed out of the possession of the House— Ingersoll’s resolutions having been transmitted to the President— The Speaker decided that a Copy only of the resolution having been transmitted to the President the resolution itself was still in the possession of the House and might be re-considered— McClelland of Illinois appealed from this decision, which after debate was sustained by the House. Dixon then supported his motion by an hour speech, Daniel of North Carolina, moved to lay Dixon’s motion to re-consider on the Table, Dixon withdrew his motion which was renewed by Lynn Boyd, with a Call for the Previous Question— This he withdrew at the request of
Yancey, between whom, and his Colleague Hilliard the controversy of Praise and Blame, concerning the character and good name, of Daniel Webster, was renewed, with aggravated malignity, on the part of Yancey— Howell Cobb renewed his motion to lay Dixon’s motion for reconsideration on the Table, Daniel moved to go into Committee of the whole on Private Bills, but Haralson moved to go into Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, which was carried Rathbun in the Chair, and the Bill from the Senate to raise a Regiment of mounted Riflemen and for the erection of Military Posts on the route to Oregon, for the protection of Emegrants was taken up, with the limitation yesterday adopted, of one hour for debate— Sundry Amendments were proposed—among which one by Felix G. McConnell to insert the word twenty before the word one, so as to make it a Bill to raise twenty-one Regiments, instead of one— Three other Members besides McConnell voted for this Amendment. Hugh White, of New York, moved that all the Officers, for the new Regiment should be selected of the regular Line, of the United States Army which was carried 78 to 71. Lewis. C. Levin of Philadelphia moved that the Officers and men, should be native Citizens of the United States— Rejected— Stanton moved to raise two Regiments instead of one. Rejected. Sundry other Amendments proposed, were also rejected and the Bill was reported with the Amendment proposed by Hugh. A. White, on which Amendment, the yeas and nays were taken in the House, and it was carried 89 to 82. George Fries, of Ohio moved a re-consideration but the House adjourned without taking the Question upon it— Evening visits from Mr. Healey and Mr. Dubourjal—

The National Intelligencer of this morning re-publishes, from the Union Newspaper of last Friday, the report of the debate in the House, on the day before, upon Charles. J. Ingersoll’s resolutions, against Daniel Webster, under the allegation, that the reporter of the Intelligencer Stansbury was en
gaged that day, in the Senate—(This is a mistake—it is the Intelligencer of Monday the 13th. that the republication from the Union is contained)—and in the House, this morning Mr. Winthrop, made a personal explanation, upon the report in the Intelligencer of yesterday, of his Speech, on this Subject, made on the day before— It related to the charge of Mr. Yancey, against Webster, of being a pensioned Agent, of the Manufacturing Interest—which Winthrop had said, was not in a just sense a true charge.— Yancey, had taken occasion to sneer, at those words—“not in a just sense,” and Mr. Webster, now explained, the words as meaning—in every just sense, and in every unjust sense, and in all senses whatsoever, and he now told, the story of the subscription of one-hundred-thousand dollars raised, from certain persons, his friends, in Boston, and invested in stocks for his benefit. His narrative was not very clear, but amounted to this, that Mr. Webster, had sold, certain valuable Western Lands at prices not exceeding their actual value, the monies for the payment of which, were raised, by this subscription of his friends, and invested by the provision of an Annuity, for life. Made without his sanction or knowledge, and announced to him here, last month— This transaction, Mr. Webster considers, highly honorable to himself, and Mr. Winthrop concurs in that opinion— Upon this explanation, Yancey, commented, with merciless severity, and questioned, Winthrop, till he shrunk from the enquiries, with loathing and disgust; remonstrating, against such torturing scrutiny into the private affairs of a Public Man— Jacob Brinkerhoff called for the orders of the day, and the debate on the Bill from the Senate, to raise a Regiment of Mounted Riflemen, and for the construction of Military Posts on the route to Oregon, for the protection of Emegrants, was resumed— George Fries of Ohio had yesterday moved, to reconsider the vote, adopting Hugh White’s Amendment that all the Officers of the Regiment, should be
selected from the United States Army, which Motion to re-consider was rejected, by yeas and nays, and after some further struggle the Bill was passed, 137. to 35— Cobb of Georgia moved a re-consideration, with a view to strike out this Amendment; which raised further debate, upon an assertion that there were now 90. supernumaOfficers, Finally the re-consideration was rejected by yeas and nays 85 to 95— Private Bills, were then taken up, and motion to re-consider the vote, rejecting the Bill, for the relief of the Heirs of Col. William Grayson, was again rejected, by yeas and nays 82. to 67— Three Private Bills were passed and after some debate upon the 4. it was also passed and the House adjourned— No evening visitors—

In the Hall of the House of Representatives the Revd. B. F. Barrett, Pastor of the Society of the New Jerusalem in the City of New York, preached from Matthew 13.31. Wherefore [“]Another parable put he forth unto them saying, the Kingdom of Heaven is like to a grain of mustard seed which a man took and sowed in his field 32. Which indeed is the least of all seeds, but when it is grown, it is the greatest among herbs, and becometh a tree, so that the Birds of the Air come and lodge in the branches thereof.” The Sermon, was an exposition of the doctrine of regeneration, as understood and represented by Emanuel Swedenborg. He did not enlarge; upon the correspondences, between the material and the spiritual world, which form the special character of the Swedenborg creed— He said little or nothing, of those millions of spiritual Beings, which Milton in the Paradise Lost says—“Walk the earth, and commune with us when we wake or when we sleep.[”] These lines appear to be the foundation of the spiritual system of Swedenborg but Mr. Barrett did not enlarge upon that part of the system. His argument was, from this Parable likening the Kingdom of Heaven to the growth of a mustard seed, proved that
regeneration, could not be effected by a sudden, and instantaneous operation but must be accomplished by slow and gradual progress, like that of the process from the sowing of the seed, to the complete formation of the tree, and the ripening of the fruit borne by it— Mr. Barrett was not eloquent, nor animated. The auditory was rather thin and Mr. Milburn Chaplain of the House made the prayer— There was no singing— After dinner, at the 2d. Presbyterian Church the Revd. Matthew Hale Smith, preached from the second Sermon of his course, addressed to young women—from 1. Timothy 5–2. “Entreat the younger women, as sisters”— His Discourse, was plain, practical, and sensible;—distinguishing the virtues, and graces, peculiarly appropriate, to young women— The Address was earnest, affectionate and impressive occasionally to the drawing of tears— He gave notice, that on the next Sunday afternoon, his third Discourse, would be specially addressed to married persons— In his exhortations to young women, I thought they would have been more effective, if he had omitted, to include in his censures the reading of novels and dancing— These I suppose, are considered, as so inadmissible to all, Clergymen, of the Calvanistic Creed, that no Clergyman of that Denomination, can forbear to press them upon the conscience of his hearers— But the morals of the Age prevail so universally, over the discipline of that Church, that I believe it would be more profitable to the success of their Preachers, if they should forbear to notice them, altogether— The censorial power of the Church must, to have any good effect, accommodate itself liberally to the Spirit of the Age— I began reading this morning the 2. Book of Samuel, why so called I do not know, and think somewhat strange in as much as the death of Samuel, is recorded in the 25th. Chapter, of the first Book that bears his name— The 2nd. Book, is confined entirely to the History of David after the death of Samuel and of Saul— The life and History of Samuel, is remarkable, as forming the link between the History of the Jews as a Republic and a Monarchy—

I received on Saturday last, a check from the Speaker of the House, for 500. dollars— I had left at the Bank of the Metropolis, on the same day, a check for the balance of my account there, with my book to be balanced— I omitted, to present the Speakers check at the Bank this day, but called at the Bank of Washington, and received a Dividend, of 105. dollars—the Interest due on the 1st. of this month on the Washington City Corporation Stocks 6. per cent, standing there in my name— At the House, of Representatives, John P. Martin of Kentucky moved to dispense with the reading of the Journal of Saturday, to take up the Mileage Bill— Motion lost and the Journal was read— Richard Brodhead of Pennsylvania, moved to discharge the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, from the Bill relating to licences for Canal Boats, to take it up in the House.— Objection being made, he moved to suspend the rules, but failed— Mr. Ashmun with leave, made a personal explanation, with relation to Yancey’s violent invective against Daniel Webster, to which Mr. Yancey at this time made no reply. The House went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, and took up, the Bill to protect the rights of American Settlers in the Territory of Oregon, until the termination of the Joint occupation of the same— Hannibal Hamlin of Maine in the Chair, The Bill, extends the jurisdiction of the Territory of Iowa over the whole of Oregon, without limitation of Boundary, beyond the Rocky Mountains— John. H. McHenry of Kentucky moved to insert the words, south of 49. degrees north.— This gave rise to a long debate in which I took part—observing that if the limitation was south of 54.40. I would vote for it, but was willing to leave it without specific limitation to the north— I refered again to my former voucher of the first Chapter of Genesis, as the foundation of Titles to Lands and produced, Grocius and Blackstone as refering to the
same identical authority—Genesis 1.26–30.— I produced also, in the 1. Vol. of the Laws of the United States page 448. the commission of George III to Governor Wright of Georgia of the 20. January 1764. reciting his commission of the 4th. of May, 1761. to the same person, revoking the first commission, extending the Boundaries of that Colony to the South Sea, and establishing, the boundaries of the second (“as far as our Territories extend”[)]—Great Britain having in the interval, by Treatise with France and Spain, bounded, her Territories, on this Continent by the Mississippi— I presented also the diversities of expression in the Nootka Sound Convention, in our Convention with Great Britain in 1818. and 1827. to shew, that Great Britain, had not a shadow of right, to any exclusive Territorial Jurisdiction on the shores of the Pacific Ocean— The Committee rose, without coming to a Question Several Executive communications were received.— I reported from the Committee of Manufactures a request to be discharged from the consideration of two memorials, and that they be refered to the Committee of Ways and Means—which was done and the House adjourned— The Senate agreed to take the Notice Question next Thursday.

Mr. Reverdy Johnson one of the Senators from the State of Maryland had sent me, a small box, containing a pair of thread Gloves, with a polite Letter from Miss Ellen M. Cockey of Jno. and Thomas . . . Forest Baltimore Co. Maryland requesting my acceptance of them, as the workmanship of her own hands which I consider as a summons to my gallantry for a complimentary answer— I took this morning my answer to Joseph Sturge of Birmingham England to the Department of State, with a request, that it might be forwarded, to Mr. Lewis McLane, our minister in England, to be transmitted by him, to Mr. Sturge—
I had a long conversation with Mr. Buchanan, upon various topics of Public concernment, and especially upon the occasional expenditure of the secret service money, and upon Mr. Buchanan’s desire, to obtain an Act of Congress constituting an Assistant Secretary of State— I stated to him my objections to this measure, upon general consideration and the imminent danger, of finding, in a Department with two heads a house divided against itself— I particularly referred him, to the result of an experiment, to establish an Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, at the first organization of the present Government of the United States and the crosses, between Alexander Hamilton and Tench Coxe, till the Office of Assistant Secretary was abolished— At the House this was the day, fixed for the consideration of the Bill for the disposal, of the Smithsonian Bequest but at the motion of the Chairman of the Select Committee Mr. Owen, it was postponed to this day week, and a Bill relative to the duty on Java Coffee already fixed for that day, was postponed for another week— John. R. J. Daniel, of North Carolina, made a personal explanation, to correct what he stated to be erroneous Reports in the Intelligencer and Union Newspapers, of a Speech made yesterday by him in Committee of the Whole— William. L. Yancey, made also an explanation, in reply to that of Mr. Ashmun yesterday— Lynn Boyd of Kentucky moved a Resolution to close the debate, on the Bill to protect the rights of American Settlers in Oregon, Thursday next at 2 o clock P.M. which after sundry abortive motions for amendment, was adopted— That Bill, was then taken up in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Hannibal Hamlin in the Chair— While the House was in Committee, a message was received from the President, supposed to be an answer, to Charles. J. Ingersoll’s Secret Service call, upon which there was a prodigious curiosity to have it immediately read. But the Speaker,
knowing it was not so, only took the Chair, to receive the message, and immediately redelivered it to Hamlin. Vinton of Ohio, Cobb of Georgia, and Holmes, of South Carolina, continued the debate, Milton Brown took the floor, and the Committee rose, McKay Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, reported the new ad valorem Tariff Bill— Objections to its reception were made and withdrawn— It was read only by its title. Andrew Stuart, moved that it be rejected—Jacob Collamer of Vermont—called for the reading of the whole Bill, the rule of the House being, that the first reading of a Bill, shall be for information— The Speaker decided, that the practise, of the House was, for the first reading to be by the title— From this decision Stuart appealed; which he afterwards withdrew. The rejection of the Bill was refused. it was read a second time by the title, I inquired if the Speaker had decided, that to read a Bill by its title, was reading it for information, as required by the rules of the House.— The Speaker said he had— I said, then the decision is directly in the face of the rule, you could as well pass the Bill now. It was referred to the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union— Joseph Grinnell of the Committee on Commerce, reported a Bill supplementary to the Act for the relief of sick and disabled seamen, and for other purposes, which was read and Committed, and the House adjourned. General Winfield Scott, was here this evening—and told me, that General Daniel Parker, who died, a few days since, was one of the two persons, who as General Scott, had informed me, on the day before Christmas 1844. were present, in February 1819. when I called upon General Andrew Jackson, to show him the Florida Treaty, then about to be concluded, and of which he then expressed his approval. In 1844. Jackson, had positively denied this fact which I had, as positively and repeatedly asserted. Scott told me, that these two persons, had separately informed him, that they were present, at this meeting, between Jackson, and me, in February 1819. but that
he was not then at liberty, to disclose to me their names. He said he was intentionally obscure, as he was now, with regard to the survivor of the two persons— But I told him I knew who he was, his name having been given to me, by Waddy Thompson, our late Minister to Mexico— Whereat, General Scott was much amazed— But I did not give him the name, following his example, of being “intentionally obscure”— Mr. Samuel. L. Gouverneur, had furnished me with several original Letters, from General Jackson to President James Monroe, amply confirming, my statement of Jacksons approval, of the Florida Treaty which he in 1844. with such brazen face denied—

I purchased this morning at the Exchange Office of Corcoran & Riggs a certificate of five hundred dolls of Washington City Corporation 6 per cent Stocks, at 1/2 of one per cent premium, for which I paid with $200 of Virginia Bank Bills, 100 dollars in half Eagles, one hundred and five dollars, in a Check in the Washington Bank, twenty six dollars and sixty cents, in 7. Napoleons, and a Check of seventy dollars and ninety cents on the Bank of the Metropolis— Amounting in all to $502.50— While musing for a suitable answer, to Miss E. M. Cockey, for her present, of a pair of gloves, I received a note, from Miss Sarah M. Benton, daughter of Mr. Thomas Hart Benton, a Senator from the State of Missouri, with her Album, in very flattering terms requesting me, to write in it some memento, of remembrance— Such repeated calls, from quarters, whence I have the least reason to expect, diversify, the public cares, already too burdensome, upon my mind, and tax severely my hours of sleep—“With knacks, trifles, nosegays, things of strong prevailment, with unhardened youth”—and form a motley composition of my life— Sarah Wilson the daughter of
Noah Wilson, came to enquire my determination, concerning the Lease, of the Lot behind my house, for a garden, to her father, which I agreed he should have for the present Season— The Lot to be measured hereafter and for 15. dollars— At the House— Yancey of Alabama made a personal explanation in reply to that of Mr. Ashmun, in denial of the charge, made by Mr. Yancey against Mr. Webster, that he was a pensioned Agent of the Manufacturers— A message was received from the President, with a Report of the Secretaries of War and Navy, concerning a Fire proof Building, for those Departments— Requiring an appropriation of $200.000. to commence the work for the present year— The Army Register for 1846— was received with a Letter from the Secretary of War— The vote of yesterday, to close the debate in the Oregon Territory Bill, to-morrow was re-considered and Friday next, was substituted in its place— The Oregon Territorial Bill, was resumed in Committee of the whole, on the state of the Union, Hannibal Hamlin in the Chair, and Milton Brown, made an hour Speech, rather fretful, than sharply pointed, against President Polk— Giles of Maryland, and Paine of Alabama succeeded, the latter of whom, rather tartly replied, to the strictures of Milton Brown upon the President— James. A. Seddon, from the 6th. Congressional District of Virginia—Richmond followed, and Gordon of New-York, after which Joseph R. Ingersoll took the floor, the Committee rose without a quorum and the House adjourned— Evening visits from Mrs. Thornton, Mrs. Talbot, and her daughter Mary, and from Mr. Wm. Hogan Jr.

Mr. Kavasales, called on me again this morning, and told me, that, he was about to go to Hartford in Connecticut, to Petition the Legislature of that State, to change his name to that of Fisk, in honor of the late President of the Methodist College at Connecticut, under whose charge, he was educated— He requested me, if I
should see the Secretary of the Navy Mr. Bancroft, I would mention to him, again his desire, to be ordered to the Squadron to the Mediterranean or to the Navy at Brooklyn— At the House, after the reception of several Reports from Committees they went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Hannibal Hamlin in the Chair, and took up the Bill, to extend the Laws of the Territory of Iowa, over that of Oregon, and for other purposes— Joseph R. Ingersoll of Philadelphia, delivered a Speech, in opposition to the whole Bill— Bradford R. Wood, of the 13th. Albany Congressional District of New York, offered a substitute of the first Section of the Bill— John. S. Phelps, of Missouri, spoke in favor of the Bill, and John. A Rockwell of Connecticut, made objections, both against the Bill and against the Amendments proposed to it— W. W. Wick of Indiana, Seaborn Jones of Georgia, and Pollock of Pennsylvania, Reuben Chapman followed— Reuben Chapman of Alabama took the floor the Committee rose and the House adjourned— We were all invited to an evening Party at Dr. Harris—but Mary Louisa only went, and Mr. Archibald Campbell, spent part of the evening with us—

Mr. Nathaniel. M. Davis, of Plymouth was here this morning.— He is a brother, to Mrs. Bancroft, wife of the Secretary of the Navy, and during his visit here, lodging at her house— On the 4th. of this month I invited Mr. William. H. Prescott, and Mr. C. Sumner of Boston then on a visit to this City to dine with us, on next Wednesday.— But they were engaged to leave the City on Tuesday. I forgot to mention this at the time— At the House this morning, a message from the Senate was received, with their concurrence, in the Resolution of the House, for giving Notice to the Government of Great Britain of the termination of the Convention of 1827. for the non occupation
of the Oregon Territory—with an Amendment, somewhat modifying the form of the notice, and of the additional resolution recommending further negotiation— Immediately after which, in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, the Oregon Territorial Bill was taken up—Hamlin in the Chair—and debated until 2. o clock, to which time the resolution of the House had already limited the debate— Then came the votes on the proposed Amendments— Of which there were many, occasioning no small desultory debate, notwithstanding the rule— They were almost all rejected, and with them, a Section authorizing the President to raise two Regiments of Mounted Men— An appropriation was reduced, from $300000. to $100.000—and among the rejections was a section offered by Robert C. Winthrop that the involuntary servitude, except for crimes, shall not exist, in the Territory of the United States, to which the Bill relates— Lost 52. to 67— The Bill was reported, and motion to adjourn was first rejected, then renewed, and carried, after an unsuccessful attempt, to adjourn over till Monday— No evening visitors—

In my ruminations of this morning, I composed a Fable, with the title of Caesar and Pompey— One of the symptoms of my desease is an itching for the composition of rhymes, which I trust will pass away, in the course of a few days, but which while it lasts, is among my worst sufferings; for it flies from subject to subject as the rheumatism in my body, flies from limb to limb— Dr. Thomas was here this morning, and ordered new prescriptions, for others, which afford me, little or no relief— At the House immediately after the reading of the Journal, the Bill to extend the Laws of Ohio, over that of Oregon and for sundry other purposes, was resumed— The Amendments reported by the Com
mittee of the whole on the state of the Union, were adopted without division, the Bill passed to a third reading and under the impulse of the Previous Question, was passed, by the yeas and nays called for by Robert. C. Winthrop—103. to 64. Winthrop Grinnell, and Julius Rockwell, of the Massachusetts Delegation voting against it— It was passed before I reached the House, and therefore I did not vote upon it at all— No member from Massachusetts voted for it— Stephen Douglass of Illinois, who, like me, was not in his seat, when his name was called, asked leave to vote; but it was refused— James Thompson of Pennsylvania moved a re-consideration, and the Previous Question— Douglass, asked for the yeas and nays in the Question; but they were refused, and the re consideration, rejected— The Amendment of the Senate to the Joint Resolution of Notice was taken up, and Robert Dale Owen, moved to concur with it, with an Amendment—and he moved a previous Question— Owens Amendment was carried by yeas and nays, 99. to 87. and the Senate’s amendment, thus amended, by 114 to 41— Pettit moved to re consider and the Previous Question— The re-consideration was refused— The House then passed to the consideration of Private Bills— Three of which were passed, after some debate. Two more were passed, after the failure of a motion to adjourn, and then the House did adjourn over to Monday—

I wrote this morning an answer to the Letter of Miss Ellen. M. Cockey—received with her present of a pair of gloves At 11. o clock this morning, I heard in the Hall of the House of Representatives, the Revd David McConaught D.D. President of the Washington College Pennsylvania, preach from Hebrews 10–38— “Now, the just shall live, by faith”— A Discourse not much above, common place, Calvanism, upon faith— Isaac Hull Adams dined with us— At
4. o clock in the afternoon I heard the Revd. Matthew Hale Smith, at the 2d. Presbyterian Church preach from Hebrews 13.4. “Marriage is honorable, in all” It was the 3d. of his intended four Discourses, and was specially addressed, to married persons— He gave notice, that the fourth and last Lecture of the series, would be delivered, next Sunday, in case of fair weather, and would be addressed to Parents— The House was very crowded, the auditory very attentive, and the Lecture, sensible, and edifying— In the evening, at the Unitarian Church, I heard the Revd. Henry W. Bellows of New York, preach, from Revelation, 2.4. “Nevertheless I have some what against thee, because, thou hast left, thy first love— 5. Remember therefore from whence thou art fallen, and repent, and do the first works”—and for a second text, Luke, 8.5—[“]A sower went out to sow his seed and as he sowed, some fell by the way side, and it was trodden down, and the fowls of the air devoured it— 6. And some fell upon a rock, and as soon as it was sprung up, it withered away, because it lacked moisture 7—And some fell among thorns: and the thorns sprung up with it, and choked it 8. And other fell on good ground and sprang up and bear fruit, an hundred fold”— Mr. Bellows composition is in the first style of elegance, and in his exposition of this text I could not, but be amused, in comparing his with that of the preacher to the Tuscororo Indians, near Niagara, which I heard near Niagara in July 1843— Mr. Bellows argument, was, that moral excellence, the practise of doing good, was the great object, of the Christian dispensation— His Sermon, was one of the most eloquent, that I ever heard, but was, said, not to be equal, to that which he had delivered, at the same Church, this morning— The House was well filled, but not over flowing— Mr. Healey and Mr. Dubourjal, paid us eveg. visits—

I wrote this morning a copy of verses in the Album of Miss Cordelia Frye—of Fryburg in the State of Maine— A Niece of my friend and brother-in-Law Nathaniel Frye, at whose house she has been spending the winter— Mr. Richard Holden was here anxious about his Memorial to the House of Representatives soliciting an appropriation of five hundred dollars to try the experiment, of his invention of a certain machine, for I know not what— Referred to the Committee of Naval Affairs in February of last year, and not reported upon, by them, at that Session— At the House—Charles J. Ingersoll offered a resolution, that the House on Thursday the 30th. of this month, for the purpose of ventilating the Hall and assuming its Summer dress, would adjourn over, till the following Monday— Objections were made, but the rules were suspended, and after several amendments proposed and rejected Ingersoll’s resolution was adopted— The House went into the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, George S. Houston in the Chair and took up the Oregon Territorial Bill with its relation to the Indian Tribes— The details of the Bill were debated for some time till a Message was received from the Presidents—in answer to the call of the House moved by Charles. J. Ingersoll on the 9th. instt. for copies, of papers, relating to the expenditures from the secret service Fund, while Daniel Webster was Secretary of State and also, for the correspondence, respecting the case of Alexander McLeod— These last papers, were furnished, with the message—but those relating to the expenditure of the secret Service money, were refused with a long exposition of reasons, the same which I had objected in opposition to the call. Jacob Thompson of Mississippi moved that they be laid on Table and printed; but withdrew the motion at the request of Charles J. Ingersoll who claimed on personal grounds, the
permission to reply to the Message. He accordingly made the reply, and repeated his charges against Webster but said that he should take no farther measures, on the subject Robert C. Winthrop made several attempts to get the floor, for animadverting upon Ingersoll’s statements to which Thomas. Butler King of Georgia, replied with great severity upon Ingersoll, but Houston of Alabama, renewed the motion, to lay the message on the Table and print it, and called the previous Question which was carried, and the main question by yeas and nays 115 to 64— Robert. Dale Owen, moved to take up the Message from the Senate notifying their disagreement to the Amendment of the House to their amendment to the Joint resolution of notice and he moved to ask a free conferrence, with the Senate on the disagreeing votes— Gentry of Tennessee, moved that the House recede— The Speaker decided, that the motion to recede took precedence, over that asking for a Committee of conferrence— Seaborn Jones of Georgia appealed from the decision, of the Speaker, which after a snarling debate was confirmed by the House, the previous question was finally called, and the motion to recede was rejected by yeas and nays, 87. to 95— Next followed Owen’s motion to insist, and ask a free conferrence, which was carried 99. to 83. A motion to reconsider that vote was made and after considerable confusion, was carried and the House adjourned— We had evening visits, from Mr. Wm Moseley, General Granger, of Canandaigua, and Mr. Gregg, of the same place—only recovered, from the effects of the accident by which he was confined, upon his return last October, from England, when I saw him at Boston—

The morning employed, in writing verses, in the Album of Miss Cordelia Frye— Professor James H. Espey, called on me this morning, and invited me, to go with him, and examine his instrument fixed on the top of the Capitol to ventilate, the Senate chamber—which I did—but understood none
the better, its operation— Mr. Espey proposes, to fix a similar machine on the top of the Capitol at the other wing, for the ventilation of the Hall of the House of Representatives— At the House, the Bill making additional appropriations, to supply difficencies, in the appropriations Bills of the last Session, was received from the Senate, with Amendments Referred to the Committee on ways and means. This was the day fixed for the consideration, of the Smithsonian Bequest Bill, which at the motion of Mr. Owen, was postponed until tomorrow The re consideration of the vote asking a conferrence with the Senate, on the Oregon Notice Resolution having been yesterday carried the question now returned and it was again carried under the previous question by yeas and nays 126. to 50— The vote was taken before I reached the House and my name was therefore not recorded, upon it. Charles. J. Ingersoll—Robert Dale Owen, and H. W. Hilliard were appointed the conferrees on the part of the House— In Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, George. S. Houston of Alabama in the Chair, the Bill reported from the Committee on Indian Affairs, to regulate Trade and intercourse, with the Indian Tribes, in the Territory of Oregon, and to preserve peace, and cultivate friendship with and among the Indians, was resumed— Allen. G. Thurman of Ohio, Jacob Thompson of Mississippi, and James A. Seddon of Virginia, proposed and debated sundry Amendments to the Bill, as did Timothy Jenkins of the 20th. Congressional District of New York, Andrew Johnson of Tennessee, and John W. Tibbatts of Kentucky— The Bill after much opposition was reported to the House, and postponed to the 2d. Monday of May. The House then adjourned by yeas and nays 98. to 67— No evening visitors—but the warm influences of Spring produced more than their usual operation upon my nervous system

I wrote this morning, verses, in the Album of Miss Sarah McDowell Benton, and took the Book, to the Senate chamber, and delivered it to her father, to be returned to her; which he promised to do— Mr. Kavasales was here, and mentioned that another person had been appointed by the Secretary of the Navy, as Chaplain to Commodore’s Reids Ship, about to sail for the Mediterranean, and he requested, that if I should see Mr. Bancroft, I would solicit for him, to be stationed at the Navy Yard here, or at Brooklyn Long Island, or at the Line of Battle Ship North Carolina, at Norfolk, which I very readily agreed to do— At the House, the Bill to establish, the Smithsonian Institution, “for the increase and diffusion of knowledge, among men”—was taken up, in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Armistead Burt of South Carolina, in the Chair— It was read through for information and then taken up, by sections for amendment— George. W. Jones of Tennessee, moved to strike out the first Section, that is to reject the Bill. Robert Dale Owen, delivered an hour Speech, in support of the Bill, dwelling chiefly upon the parts of it, appropriating Funds, to the education and training of teachers for Normal Schools—throughout the Union. In my opinion the worst feature of the Bill—Jones objection, was chiefly to the organization, of the Trustees of the Fund as a Corporation, which he contended was not within the Constitutional power of Congress, to create— After Owen’s Speech, Jones withdrew his motion to strike out the first Section, and moved to amend, by a Section authorizing the whole Bequest, to be returned, to the Heirs at Law, or next of kin, or residuary Legatees, of Smithson, or their authorized Agents, whenever they shall demand the Same— That is to say to deliver to them the State Bonds, of the state of Arkansas Illinois, and Michigan, upon which neither interest nor principal, is, or is soon likely, to be paid— This is Mr. Jones’
favourite mode, of disposing of a Fund, accepted by the Congress of the United States, with the pledge of their faith, that it should be appropriated to the purposes, prescribed; by the donor— This motion was discussed, by the mover, by Joseph R. Ingersoll, by F. P. Stanton of Tennessee, by William Sawyer of Ohio and by Jefferson Davis of Mississippi— After which the Committee rose without coming to any conclusion. Richard Brodhead of Pennsylvania, moved to discharge the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union from the consideration of the Bill relative to Licences to Canal Boats, the motion was carried and the Bill debated in the House till Samuel Gordon, moved that it be recommitted to the Committee of Commerce. On the question put there were ayes 47. noes 48. no quorum and the House adjourned—

I received some time since a Letter from George. W. Holley Guardian of Peter Augustus Porter, son of the late General Peter B. Porter, late of Niagara Falls, requesting a Letters of introduction for Mr. Porter who is going to Berlin to connect himself with its University for the purpose of continuing his studies He was graduated last Summer, with honor, at Harvard University— Mr. Holley requests me to send the Letters under the care of Mr. Abbott Lawrence Boston, before the first of next month, when Mr. Porter proposes to embark. I wrote Letters therefore, to Mr. Louis McLane, our Minister, and Colonel Thomas Aspinwall our Consul at London, and to Mr. William. R. King, Minister and Mr. Robert Walsh Consul, at Paris. I would also, have written to Mr. Henry Wheaton our Minister at Berlin but that he has been recalled, it is said at his own request— At the House, Lynn Boyd, moved a resolution to close debate in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, on the Smithsonian Bequest Bill, in half an hour, after
after taking it up in Committee.— Joseph. R. Ingersoll, pleaded for an hour and a half, James Graham of North Carolina, moved to lay the resolution on the Table, which was done— And the House went into Committee again, Armistead Burt in the Chair, and resumed the consideration of the Bill.— Charles. J. Ingersoll, informed the House that the managers of the conference upon the Notice disagreement, had unanimously agreed upon a Report, but that it could not be communicated to this House, until it should have been acted upon by the Senate— George. P. Marsh of Vermont, made an hour speech upon the Smithsonian Bequest Bill— One of the best Speeches, ever delivered in the House, but not much in support of the Bill— His desire, is, to apply a very large portion, of the annual interest, upon the Fund, to the establishment of a public Library— Isaac. E. Morse, of Louisiana, to whom, Owen replied, and was followed by John. S. Chipman of Michigan, against the Bill— The Committee rose, and Owen moved a resolution to close the debate in Committee of the whole. Joseph. R. Ingersoll moved to amend by inserting three hours, but the resolution itself was laid on the Table, 93. to 44. Owen asked if a resolution allowing an hour and a half would be acceptable, I requested him not to renew the question in any form, as I wished to offer a substitute for the whole Bill— Objection was made to this, I moved a suspension of the rules which was carried— I proposed my substitute, which I had prepared this morning, it was referred to the Committee of the Whole on the state of the Union, and ordered to be printed— The consideration of the Bill was then postponed to next Monday and the Bill relating to licences to Canal Boats, was taken up—and supported by a Speech by Mr. Joseph Grinnell— A message came from the Senate that the Senate had agreed to a Report of the Managers of the conference on the Oregon Notice resolution— The Report was then produced and read by Charles. J. Ingersoll, Chairman of the Committee of conference on the
part of the House, on which Gentry of Tennessee made some remarks— John. A. McClernand of Illinois, asked to be excused from voting and assigns his reasons, which were it would be an instruction to the President, to compromise, on the Columbia River, and then withdrew his request to be excused— The Report of the Committee was accepted 142. to 46. George. W. Jones of Tennessee moved to reconsider, and the Previous Question—the reconsideration was refused without division and the House adjourned— We spent the evening with a party at Mr. W. W. Seatons Junior Editor of the National Intelligencer and Mayor of the City of Washington—

I enclosed this morning, to Mr. Peter Augustus Porter, at Boston to the care of Mr. Abbott Lawrence, the letters of introduction which I had yesterday written, at the request of Mr. Holley, Mr. Porters Guardian, and dispatched it by the Mail— I received from Mr. William S Russell of Plymouth, dated on the 21st. instt. a Letter of inquiry—concerning the first settlement at Weymouth, called Wessagusens, with a Copy of a Letter of my father, of the 18th. May 1822, to the Printer of the Old Colony Memorial, on the subject— These enquiries, I am very imperfectly prepared to answer— At the House, J. I. McKay, Chairman of the Committee ways and means, reported, a recommendation, to concur with the Amendments of the Senate, to the dificency appropriation Bill— The Bill and Amendments, were referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, McKay, by instruction of the Committee of Ways and Means moved, to print a thousand extra copies of the new Tariff Bill, but upon objection being made, withdrew the motion. The Canal Boat Licence Bill was then taken up—and Mr Joseph Grinnell concluded his speech, interrupted
yesterday, against the Bill, with the offer of a substitute Joseph. R. Ingersoll, spoke, against the substitute, without favoring the Bill and James Pollock, of the 13th. Congressional Dist. Pennsylvania, concurred with Ingersoll against the substitute but favored the Bill. McKay, closed a speech against both, by moving to lay the Bill on the Table, and calling the yeas and nays, his motion was rejected 41. to 105, The debate was continued, by Hamlin of Maine. McClernand, of Illinois, Brodhead of Pennsylvania, and Preston King of New York, Mr Grinnell’s substitute was adopted, and the Bill passed, and was sent to the Senate— Committee of the whole on the State of the Union. Jacob Thompson in the Chair. Post Office Appropriation Bill was taken up— The first item, was for transportation of the Mails three-million-and fifty-thousand dollars.— McKay to increase it twenty-five thousand dollars, for the Line of Mail Steamers, from New York to Bremen upon which followed a long debate, upon a contract of the Post Master General, for the establishment of his Line of Steamers— The Committee rose without coming to any conclusion. the Speaker laid before the House, a Report from the Secretary of the Navy, upon retrenchment and accountability which was laid on the Table, and the House adjourned— The Revd. Mr. Matthew Hale Smith Minister of the 2nd. Presbyterian Church, was here this evening— Mrs. Ann Herren Jessup, daughter of the late Major William Craughan of Kentucky and wife of General Thomas S. Jesup of the United States Army, died this morning at the age of 48— An excellent woman, with whom and her family a very friendly intimacy has for many years subsisted with ours—

To the Sun—eclipsed—
A Sonnet—

lg.l: Celestial source of light and life on earth
What envious rival intercepts thy rays.
Dares thy own satellite arrest thy blaze,
Or stay thy stream of empirean birth.
Is it, that ever, of transcendant worth
The mortal doom to win the meed of praise
Is to be mir’d through slanders, slimy ways,
Or fly for refuge to the Hermits hearth—
Pure emanation from God’s holy throne
Thy beam albeit with passing splendor bright
Yielding alternate to the realm of night
Each dim eclipse or transient cloud obscures—

div.p:
These lines were written, on the occasion of the solar eclipse, which this day took place— By the invitation of Lieut. Maury, who has now the charge, of the Astronomical Observatory at the Depot of Chartes and Maps, attached to the Navy Department, in this City— I went there, to observe this eclipse, through the great Frauenhofer Refractor which is there established: But the atmosphere was so beclouded, that I lost the opportunity of the observation—and remained there; not more than half an hour— Lieut Maury told me, that the calculation of this eclipse, by Mr. Robert. T. Paine, had fixed, within two seconds, the time of its commencement.— a prediction more accurate, than any other, that he had ever known, ten seconds having been considered, the nearest approach to perfect accuracy, attainable, by Astronomical observers— I met there, Mr. Charles Ashley a Member of the United States Senate, from the State of Arkansas, with his wife, and several other Ladies— I proceeded from thence, immediately to the Capitol where I found the House in Session. McKay, Chairman of the Committee of ways and means, had renewed his motion, yesterday made, and withdrawn, to print a thousand extra copies, of the new Tariff Bill, which after several votes without a quorum, was carried, McKay moved also, to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union on the dificient Appropriation Bill
which was refused. And the House took up Private Bills, two of which were rejected, and adopted, one— Then went into Committee of the whole and took up a Bill, for allowing the Fishing Bounty to the owner and Crew of the Schooner Success, lost at Sea, twenty days, before she had completed her Fishing voyage, of four months. Mr. Grinnell, made a very efficient speech, in favor of the Bill, and was warmly supported by Luther Severance, of Maine— Samuel Gordon moved to report the Bill with a recommendation that it be rejected. I moved, as an Amendment to strike out the recommendation, and report the Bill—which, was carried— The Bill for the relief of Nathaniel Bird was after debate reported to the House. The Committee rose and the House adjourned—

I attended Public Worship this morning and the Revd. Dr. Adams of New York City preached from Romans 15.4— “For whatsoever things were written aforetime were written for our learning that we, through patience and comfort of the Scriptures, might have, hope”— The discourse, was an argumentative exposition of the whole text, showing how the Scriptures, of the Old Testament were adapted to teach the Christian reader by patience and of investigation, and the comfort derived through the perusal and study of them may be encouraged, to entertain the hope, of salvation and blessedness, in the future life— It was very ingenious, impressive, and eloquent— After dinner, at the Second Presbyterian Church, this day had been fixed, by Mr. Smith, for the delivery of the 4th and last, of his series of Lectures. The one addressed particularly to Parents—and the weather was so unpropitious the day consisting of a succession of showers, that he postponed the delivery of this Lecture till the next Sabbath—and preached upon Isaiah, 55–10— [“]For as the rain cometh down and the snow, from Heaven and returneth
not thither but watereth the earth and maketh it bring forth, and bud, that it may give seed to the sower, and bread to the eater; 11. So shall my word be, that goeth forth, out of my mouth, it shall not return unto me, void, but it shall accomplish that which I please, and it shall prosper, in the thing whereto I sent it”— This was a very seasonable, discourse with reference, to the time of its delivery, and the analogies between the effects of the rain and snow described in the first verse, and the influences of the Holy Scriptures upon the happiness of mankind, ascerted in the second, were commented upon, and dilated sensibly, and judiciously by the Preacher— In the evening at the Unitarian Church I heard the Revd. Henry. W. Bellows of New York preach from John 15.11. “These things have I spoken unto you, that my joy, might remain in you, and that your joy might be full”— The drift of the Discourse was, that the mission of Christ upon earth was to promote, the happiness of mankind and that the text itself indissolubly connected the joy of the Redeemer, with the fullness of joy of his Apostles and of all his Disciples in all ages— It was full of instruction, and eloquence, but not quite so impressive, as that of the last Sunday evening— I met Mr. Bellows and his lady last Thursday evening at Mr. Seatons— On my return I found Mr. Healey and Mr. Dubourjal here.

In the British House of Commons, on the 20th. last month, Lord George Benti a Son of the Duke of Portland, charged me, by name, for blasphemously, he would say, calling to my aid the word of God, as a justification for lighting up fire-brands and unleashing the Hell hounds of war, on as he called it “our” Territory of Oregon, and he proceeded to say “that if it came to this, that the Bible should be quoted for the title of the
Americans to the Oregon Territory, he trusted, he would be enabled to address the Americans in the language of British thunder, from the broadsides of a Line of Battle Ship (hear, hear) and that they would send, British Seamen to the Seaboard of America, to speak in terms, that could not be misunderstood, and make assirtion of our rights (hear, hear)” The report of this debate is re-published, in several newspapers of this Country, and particularly in the Baltimore Sun, of last Thursday, the 23d. instt. I deem it my duty to reply to this charge, and if possible in my seat in the House of Representatives— But if done at all, it must be done with great deliberation, and in a written Speech— I began this morning the draught of this speech and I pray to God, for resolution, decision, and discretion to go through the fiery ordeal, of accomplishing it— At the House, Charles. J. Ingersoll, asked leave to make a personal explanation upon which objection being made, he moved and carried a suspension of the rules— George. Ashmun said he wished to move an Amendment to Ingersoll’s motion, which the Speaker said, could not be done— The suspension was carried out yeas and nays 102. to 25, and Ingersoll, delivered a new written attack upon Daniel Webster, for corruption, and embezzlement of Public money, and, delinquency in the settlement of his accounts, as Secretary of State— He concluded, by asking for a Committee which he said, he could not institute to test the truth of his statements— Ashmun asked leave to reply, and upon objection made, the rules were again suspended 125. to 22. and Ashmun did reply by a defence of Mr. Webster, and retorted, charges against Charles. J. Ingersoll in which process, he was repeatedly interrupted by calls to order, but sustained by the Speaker, and grossly insulted, by foul language, of charges of lying and cowardice, from Ingersoll— In the course of this debate, the Speaker decided that when all the rules of the House were suspended, the Parliamentary Law of England, was, still obligatory upon this House— I
called upon him for his authority, in making his decision, he said it was my own, appealing to a decision, which he said I had made, while presiding over the House, at the first Session, of the 26th. Congress. I denied having ever made such a decision, and he did not attempt to produce it— I cannot find upon the Journal of the House, of that Session, any Question decided by me, which the Speaker, could even construe, into a precedent, for his decision of this day— Upon Mr. Ashmun’s pressing some of his charges against Charles. J. Ingersoll, he went over, to implore the assistance of his brother Joseph, to extricate him, from trouble; which he did, as far as he was able, with great propriety, and sensibility— This discreditable scene, closed, with a resolution offered by Mr. Schenck of Ohio, for the appointment of a Committee, of five members, to investigate the Question, how and in what manner, and by whom, Charles. J. Ingersoll had obtained secret documents, from the Department, of State, and report to the House, as soon as practicable the result of their investigation and by the appointment of another Committee also of five members, to inquire into the truth of the charges made by Charles. J. Ingersoll, against Daniel Webster with a view to founding an impeachment against him— The appointment of both Committees was carried and both have power to call for persons or papers, books and vouchers.
