Howell Cobb of Georgia, moved that all debate in Committee of the whole on the Smithsonian Bequest Bill, should cease in two hours, after it should be next taken up—but this was rejected after an abortive attempt to lay it on the Table— Two Messages from the President were received, with reports from the Secretary of War, relating to Treatise with the Choctaw Indians— The Messages were laid on the Table and the House adjourned— I took a walk after dinner.— The weather oppressively warm— We had evening visits from Mr. Mosely member of the House from the Buffalo District of New York, and Mr. Osburn, one of his Constituents— Mr. Mosely, has recovered.

I prepared this morning, a draught of a Bill, to be proposed, as a substitute for that, reported by the Smithsonian Committee, parts of which, are to me so exceptionable that I should prefer postponement, of the whole subject, to another session, rather than see it adopted— At the House, the Committee appointed by the Speaker, of inquiry upon Charles Ingersoll’s, invasion, upon the secresy, of the Department of State, was announced to be, Robert. C. Schenck of Ohio, James. C. Dobbin of North Carolina, Abraham. R. McIlvaine of Pennsylvania, Allen. G. Thurman, of Ohio, and John. A. Rockwell of Connecticut, and the Committee of investigation upon the conduct of Daniel Webster as Secretary of State is John Pettit of Indiana, Samuel. F. Vinton of Ohio Jefferson Davis of Mississippi Daniel P. King of Massachusetts, and, David Wilmot of Pennsylvania.— Mr Thurman, asked to be, and was, excused from serving, as he was under the necessity of being absent in the course of a few days, and F. P. Stanton of Tennessee was appointed in his place— The use of the Hall was granted, for an exhibition of the blind pupils from the institutions of Boston, Philadelphia, and Virginia this evening— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Armistead Burte in the Chair, on the Smithsonian Bequest Bill Simms of South Carolina, opposed the Bill, in every shape and form, it could assume.— He held Congress had no power by the Constitution to accept such a trust, and was for returning the money, to the Chancery of England— I made a desultary speech, in support of the substitute, proposed by me, for the Bill— They were both debated, till the Committee rose without coming to a conclusion, and other amendments were proposed. George. W. Hopkins of Virginia, moved a resolution to close the debate in Committee of the whole, in one hour, after it should be next taken up, which was carried, by means of the Previous Question, and the House adjourned— Mr. John. A. Rockwell of Connecticut and his wife were here this evening—

Mr. Ira Webster, a travelling book-sellers Agent was here, with certain Books for sale none of which were wanted by me— Mr. Kavasales called, and repeated his desire, for active employment again in his capacity as a Chaplain in the Navy— I had not seen the Secretary of the Navy since Mr. Kavasales was last here, but I promised him, I would call at the Navy Department, and speak in his favor to Mr. Bancroft before the end of the week.— At the House, after the passage of certain resolutions, relating to the Post Office establishment and from the Committee on Engraving, Robert Smith, of Illinois, asked leave to introduce a Bill of which he had given notice respecting the publication of the Laws in the Western States and Territories. But the leave was refused— The Committee of the whole on the State of the Union on the Smithsonian Bequest Bill Armistead Burte in the Chair— The Bill reported by the Committee, was debated, and several of its sections struck out at my motion. My own, offered substitute was rejected 57. to 74— William J. Hough of the 23d. Congressional District of New York, moved another substitute, to which George. P. Marsh, moved sundry Amendments, the most important of which was, a Section appropriating $25000— a year from the interest of the Fund, for the formation of a Public Library— These amendments were carried and the Bill thus amended, was reported to the House, there under the Previous Question, it was passed to a third reading by yeas and nays 81. to 76. and then passed 85. to 76— At both which times, I voted in the affirmative— Owen, voted against the engrossment, but voted for the final passage— Thus nearly the whole proceeds of the Bequest are devoted to the annual accumulation of a great national Public Library. The best disposal of the Fund, which it has been practicable to obtain and which, at least to a great degree will I hope escape the usual fate of all benevolent Institutions of being degraded, into mere, jobs, for hungry speculation—
The usual motion for reconsideration of the vote passing the Bill, was made by Mr. Owen and rejected without a division. George. W. Hopkins moved to adjourn, to nine o clock tomorrow morning, with a view to adjourn immediately then, over to next Monday, for ventilation and the Summer dress for the Hall, as had already been agreed upon, and the House adjourned accordingly Evening visits from Mr. Buchanan Secretary of State and from Mr. William Hogan—

At nine o clock this morning, I attended at the House of Representatives, where, John W. Tibbatts, presented a Memorial for the Institutions of Massachusetts Pennsylvania, Kentucky, Ohio, Virginia, and New York, praying for an appropriation for printing elementary and standard Books, for the use and instruction of the blind, to be deposited with the Executive of the several states, for distribution— He moved its referrence to a Select Committee and that it should be printed, but pending the question the House adjourned over to next Monday— I returned home, and received visits from Mr. Moorehead, one of the Senators from the state of Kentucky with a friend of his from the same state— I am endeavouring to take advantage of the few days of leisure allowed by the adjournment of the House, till next Monday to recover the arrears of this Journal, and to prepare, my answer to Lord George Bentinck, for which however, I fear I shall not have sufficient time— There is an amusing paper War, between the Administration Union Newspaper, and the Whig National Intelligencer, upon the Question, which party has won the victory upon the Oregon Notice Battle— The Union shouts victory, for the Administration— The Intelligencer whistles victory for the whigs.— Driven, horse, foot and Dragoons, from their cry of
War, war, at the very sound of the word notice, now, when the measure is carried, by majorities of three to one, in both Houses of Congress, they trim their sail to the breeze, and shout hozanna’s to the Senate, for sugar in the pill, with soft words, and recommending further amicable negotiation, for adjustment of differences— The Intelligencer of this morning, has an editorial Article, from a respected correspondant, crowing like a six weeks cockrel, victory to the Whigs, and defeat and rebuke to the Administration No evening visitors—
